questions.text: A 60-year-old male with a history of persistent hoarseness, throat pain, and difficulty swallowing was recently diagnosed with Laryngeal Carcinoma. Which of the following is not a known risk factor for developing laryngeal cancer in this patient?

choices.text: Genetic predisposition due to Fanconi anemia

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Exposure to EBV

 

Explanation:

EBV are associated with Nasopharyngeal carcinoma and are less commonly linked to laryngeal cancer compared to other risk factors.

 

Risk Factors and Etiology of Laryngeal Cancer:

  • Tobacco Use:(most common cause)
    • Smoking is a well-established risk factor due to carcinogens like benzopyrene and other hydrocarbons.
  • Alcohol Consumption:
    • Alcohol use is a significant risk factor, with a synergistic effect when combined with smoking.
  • Synergistic Effect:
    • The combined effect of tobacco and alcohol is greater than the sum of their individual effects and has a 15-fold increased risk of laryngeal cancer compared to using either factor alone. (Option A ruled out)
  • Radiation Exposure:
    • Previous radiation treatment to the neck for benign conditions or laryngeal papilloma can increase the risk of developing laryngeal cancer.
  • Genetic Factors:
    • Reports from Japanese and Russian studies suggest that genetic predisposition may play a role in familial cases of laryngeal cancer.
    • Genetic syndromes like Fanconi anemia and congenital dyskeratosis are also associated with a higher risk. (Option B ruled out)
  • Occupational Exposure:
    • Exposure to occupational hazards such as asbestos, polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons, wood dust, coal dust, cement dust, mustard gas, and petroleum products has been linked to laryngeal cancer. (Option C ruled out)
  • Demographic Data:
    • Laryngeal cancer is significantly more common in males compared to females, with a reported incidence of 3.99% in males and 0.46% in females.
    • Lower socioeconomic status and manual ‘blue-collar’ occupations also experience a higher risk.
  • HPV
    • HPV 6 and 11 cause juvenile respiratory papillomatosis which rarely undergoes malignant change
    • Sexual behaviors and HPV infection are strongly associated with oropharyngeal cancers, but there is limited epidemiological evidence connecting these factors with laryngeal cancers.
    • Unlike oropharyngeal cancer, current studies do not show an improved prognosis for HPV-positive laryngeal tumors.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male presents with progressive hoarseness of voice and mild dyspnea on exertion. He underwent coronary artery bypass grafting 6 months ago. A fiberoptic laryngoscopy reveals left-sided vocal cord paralysis in the paramedian position. A chest CT scan shows no mediastinal mass or aortic enlargement. Electromyography of the laryngeal muscles reveals denervation. What is the most likely cause of his vocal cord paralysis?

choices.text: Left atrial enlargement due to mitral valve disease
Post-surgical trauma to the recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN)
Compression of the recurrent laryngeal nerve by aortic aneurysm

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Post-surgical trauma to the recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN)

 

Explanation:

The given scenario involves delayed unilateral vocal cord paralysis (ULVCP) following coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), with an absence of extrinsic compressive factors like a mediastinal mass or aortic aneurysm.

  • The left RLN is anatomically vulnerable during thoracic surgeries like CABG due to its course under the aortic arch.
  • Surgical trauma, especially stretching or manipulation during cardiac or thoracic procedures, can result in delayed RLN injury, manifesting as vocal cord paralysis.
  • Electromyography (EMG) showing denervation of laryngeal muscles supports a nerve injury rather than compression.

 

Causes of Vocal Cord paralysis:

  • Malignancy
  • Iatrogenic surgical trauma
  • Idiopathic
  • Non-surgical trauma
  • Intubation
  • Neurological disorders
  • Infections - Lyme disease, Herpes zoster, EBV, HSV, CMV, in immunocompromised patients.

 

Surgical procedures associated with vocal cord paralysis:

Cervical surgery
  • Thyroidectomy/parathyroidectomy
  • Carotid endarterectomy
  • Anterior approach to the cervical spine
  • Repair Zenker’s diverticulum
  • Cricopharyngeal myotomy

Thoracic procedures
  • Thoracic aneurysm repair
  • Pneumonectomy
  • Aortic valve repair
  • Coronary artery bypass grafting
  • Esophageal or tracheal surgery
  • Mediastinoscopy
  • Ligation of patent ductus arteriosus

Others
  • Skull base or brainstem surgery
  • Endotracheal intubation

 

Causes of SLN Injury:

  • Trauma - surgical or accidental
  • Neuritis (mostly diphtheritic)
  • Pressure by cervical nodes
  • Involvement in a neoplastic process

 

Causes of RLN Injury:

  • Trauma to the neck
  • Thyroid disease and surgery
  • CA cervical esophagus, CA apex of right lung
  • Cervical lymphadenopathy
  • Subclavian artery aneurysm
  • Tuberculosis of cervical pleura
  • Idiopathic

 

Additionally, the Left RLN (which has a longer course than the right) can be injured in the mediastinum due to:

  • Bronchogenic cancer
  • Carcinoma thoracic esophagus
  • Aortic aneurysm
  • Mediastinal lymphadenopathy
  • Idiopathic
  • Enlarged left auricle
  • Intrathoracic surgery

 

Left atrial enlargement due to mitral valve disease (Option A):

  • While left atrial enlargement from mitral valve disease can compress the left RLN as it loops around the aortic arch (causing Ortner’s syndrome), this patient has no echocardiographic or clinical evidence of mitral valve disease or left atrial enlargement.

 

Compression of the recurrent laryngeal nerve by aortic aneurysm (Option C):

  • Aortic aneurysms can cause RLN compression, leading to left-sided vocal cord paralysis.
  • However, in this case, the chest CT scan ruled out aortic aneurysm or other compressive lesions, making this diagnosis less likely.

 

Idiopathic unilateral vocal cord paralysis (Option D):

  • Idiopathic causes account for a significant portion (20%) of unilateral vocal cord paralysis.
  • However, given this patient’s history of recent cardiac surgery, an idiopathic cause is less likely than iatrogenic trauma.

questions.text: In a patient who has undergone a total laryngectomy, a portable vocal rehabilitation device needs to be prescribed immediately post-surgery. Choose the device from the given options:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Electrolarynx

 

Explanation:

  • The electrolarynx allows for immediate speech production after surgery, making it a practical solution for patients who need to communicate right away.
  • It is a transistorized, battery-operated portable device.

Vocal rehabilitation-methods:

  • After laryngectomy, the patient loses his speech completely.
  • The various methods by which communication can be established are given below:

 

Oesophageal Speech

  • In this, the patient is taught to swallow air and hold it in the upper esophagus and then slowly eject it from the esophagus into the pharynx.
  • The patient can speak 6-10 words before re-swallowing air.
  • The voice is rough but loud and understandable.

 

Artificial Larynx It is used in those who fail to learn oesophageal speech.

 

  • Electrolarynx:
    • Its vibrating disc is held against the soft tissues of the neck and a low-pitched sound is produced in the hypopharynx which is further modulated into speech by the tongue, lips, teeth, and palate.

 

  • Transoral pneumatic device (Option B)
    • It is a transoral device.
    • Here vibrations produced in a rubber diaphragm are carried by a plastic tube into the back of the oral cavity where sound is converted into speech by modulators.
    • This is a pneumatic type of device and uses expired air from the tracheostome to vibrate the diaphragm.

 

Tracheo-Oesophageal Speech

  • Here an attempt is made to carry air from the trachea to the esophagus or hypopharynx by the creation of a skin-lined fistula or by placement of an artificial prosthesis.
  • The vibrating column of air entering the pharynx is then modulated into speech.
  • This technique has the disadvantage of food entering the trachea.
  • These days prostheses (Blom-Singer or Panje) are being used to shunt air from the trachea to the esophagus (Option C)
  • They have inbuilt valves which work only in one direction thus preventing problems of aspiration.

questions.text: In a patient diagnosed with stage 3 laryngeal carcinoma with no involvement of thyroid cartilage, the patient is unwilling to undergo chemoradiotherapy. What will be the treatment of choice in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Total laryngectomy

 

Explanation:

In the given case scenario of stage 3 laryngeal carcinoma with no involvement of thyroid cartilage since the patient is not willing to do chemoradiotherapy, total laryngectomy would be the treatment of choice.

 

Treatment of Stage 3 and Stage 4A of Laryngeal Carcinoma:

  • Concurrent Chemo-RT: for stage 3 and early stage 4 (Cisplatin/ Carboplatin/Cetuximab).
    • This treatment is suitable for all the stage 3 & stage 4a cases which do not involve any cartilage(thyroid/cricoid).
  • Near Total Laryngectomy: Stage 3 and Stage 4a cases with one arytenoid spared.
    • It is the treatment of choice in stage 3 & stage 4a cases involving thyroid/cricoid cartilage.

 

Total laryngectomy

Indications:

  1. T4a with thyroid cartilage invasion.
  2. Stage 3 and 4a who cannot tolerate chemotherapy.
  3. Stage 3 and 4 recurrent tumours
  4. Bilateral arytenoid involvement.

 

Conservative Surgery (Option B) is done in cases of recurrence when the radiation therapy fails to treat.

 

Micro laryngeal surgery (Option C) is done for stages 1 and 2 when the carcinoma is in the middle 1⁄ 3 of the vocal cord.

 

Vertical hemilaryngectomy (Option D) is done in cases of recurrence where one-half of the larynx (vertical) is involved along with subglottic extension not more than 1cm.

  • This is a type of conservative surgery done in stages 1 and 2 of laryngeal carcinoma.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient is diagnosed with glottic carcinoma involving the right side of the vocal cord. The tumor extends to the supraglottis with impaired vocal cord mobility. What is the most appropriate primary treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Vertical hemilaryngectomy

 

Explanation:

  • According to stage grouping, T2N0M0 glottic carcinoma is grouped under Stage II.
  • For Stage II carcinoma along with impaired cord mobility, radiotherapy is not preferred because of the possibility of developing perichondritis which would require total laryngectomy afterwards.
  • For these patients, the best option is to do conservative surgery such as vertical hemilaryngectomy.

 

Treatment of Stage I and Stage II Laryngeal Carcinoma

TNM Staging

Stage Grouping

Treatment

T1N0M0

Stage I

Glottic- Radiotherapy or Endoscopic CO2 laser resection

Supraglottic- Radiotherapy or Endoscopic CO2 laser resection

Subglottic- Radiotherapy

T2N0M0

Stage II

Glottic-

  • Radiotherapy- when the cord is mobile
  • Vertical hemilaryngectomy- when cord mobility is impaired or Involvement of anterior commissure/arytenoid

Supraglottic-

  • Supraglottic laryngectomy with/without neck dissection- when lung function is good
  • Supraglottic laryngectomy with/without neck dissection + Radiotherapy- when lung function is poor
 

Subglottic- Radiotherapy

 

Total laryngectomy (Option A) is not the primary choice of treatment in T2 laryngeal carcinoma. It is mostly preferred for T3 and T4.

 

Radiotherapy (Option B) alone will not be sufficient, as the patient has impaired vocal cord mobility and is showing vocal cord involvement.

 

Endoscopic CO2 laser excision (Option C) is done only in cases where vocal cord mobility is not impaired.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with hoarseness and difficulty swallowing. Laryngoscopy reveals a tumor involving both vocal cords with normal mobility. There is no evidence of spread beyond the larynx or lymph node involvement. Based on the TNM classification of laryngeal carcinoma, what is the most appropriate staging for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) T1b N0

 

Explanation:

  • Based on the site of lesion, the patient has a diagnosis of glottic laryngeal carcinoma.
  • Tumor limited to both vocal cords represents T1b stage of glottic laryngeal carcinoma.

 

Supraglottis

T1

Tumor is limited to one subsite of supraglottis with normal vocal cord mobility.

T2

Tumor invades mucosa of more than one adjacent subsites of supraglottis or glottis or region outside the supraglottis (e.g. mucosa of base of tongue, vallecula, medial wall of pyriform sinus) without fixation of the larynx.

T3

Tumor is limited to the larynx with vocal cord fixation and/or invades any of the following: postcricoid area, pre-epiglottic tissues, paraglottic space and/or minor thyroid cartilage invasion.

T4a

Tumor invades through the thyroid cartilage and/or invades tissues beyond the larynx (e.g. trachea, soft tissues of neck including deep extrinsic muscle of tongue, strap muscles, thyroid or esophagus).

T4b

Tumor invades prevertebral space, encases carotid artery or invades mediastinal structures

 

Glottis

T1

Tumor limited to vocal cord(s) (may involve anterior or posterior commissures) with normal mobility.

T1a

Tumor is limited to one vocal cord. (Option A)

T1b

Tumor involves both vocal cords.

T2

Tumor extends to supraglottis and/or subglottis, and/or with impaired vocal cord mobility. (Option C)

T3

Tumor is limited to the larynx with vocal cord fixation and/or invades paraglottic space and/or minor thyroid cartilage erosion. (Option D)

T4a

Tumor invades through thyroid cartilage and/or invades tissues beyond the larynx (e.g. trachea, soft tissues of neck including deep extrinsic muscles of the tongue, strap muscles, thyroid, or esophagus).

T4b

Tumor invades prevertebral space, encases the carotid artery or invades mediastinal structures.

 

Subglottis

T1

Tumor is limited to the subglottis.

T2

Tumor extends to the vocal cord(s) with normal or impaired mobility.

T3

Tumor limited to larynx with vocal cord fixation.

T4a

Tumor invades cricoid or thyroid cartilage and/or invades tissues beyond the larynx (e.g. trachea, soft tissues of neck including deep extrinsic muscle of tongue, strap muscles, thyroid or esophagus).

T4b

Tumor invades prevertebral space, encases the carotid artery or invades mediastinal structures.

 

Regional lymph nodes (N)

Nx

Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed.

N0

No regional lymph node metastasis.

N1

Metastasis in a single ipsilateral lymph node, 3 cm or less in greatest dimension.

N2

Metastasis in a single ipsilateral lymph node, more than 3 cm but not more than 6 cm in greatest dimension, or multiple ipsilateral lymph nodes, none more than 6 cm in greatest dimension, or bilateral or contralateral lymph nodes, none more than 6 cm in the greatest dimension.

N2a

Metastasis in a single ipsilateral lymph node more than 3 cm but not more than 6 cm in greatest dimension.

N2b

Metastasis in multiple ipsilateral lymph nodes, none more than 6 cm in greatest dimension.

N2c

Metastasis in bilateral or contralateral lymph nodes, none more than 6 cm in greatest dimension

Na

Metastasis in a lymph node more than 6 cm in the greatest dimension

 

Distant metastasis

Mx

Distant metastasis cannot be assessed

M0

No Distant metastasis

M1

Distant metastasis

 

References:

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presents with progressive stridor and difficulty breathing for the past 2 months. Laryngoscopy reveals a mass in the subglottic region with normal appearing and mobile vocal cords. Which of the following statements about subglottic carcinoma is incorrect?

choices.text: Hoarseness is typically a late symptom
Lymphatic spread is common to prelaryngeal and paratracheal nodes
It often presents with airway obstruction as an early symptom
Prognosis is generally better than glottic carcinoma

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Prognosis is generally better than glottic carcinoma

 

Explanation:

Prognosis for subglottic carcinoma is generally worse than glottic carcinoma because of:

  • Late symptomatology
  • Early lymphatic spread
  • Poor differentiation on histopathological examination

 

Subglottic laryngeal carcinoma:

Incidence

Least common site of laryngeal cancer (1-5% of cases)

Site

Extends from undersurface of vocal cords to lower border of cricoid cartilage

Vocal cord involvement

Usually late; vocal cords often appear normal in early stages

Local Spread

Can spread circumferentially, invade cricothyroid membrane, thyroid gland, and trachea

Lymphatic spread

Common to prelaryngeal, pretracheal, paratracheal, and lower jugular nodes (Option B)

Symptoms

Early: Stridor, laryngeal obstruction (Option C)

Late: Hoarseness, cough, hemoptysis (Option A)

Histopathology

Poorly differentiated

Predominantly squamous cell carcinoma

Prognosis

Generally worse than glottic carcinoma due to late diagnosis and higher rate of lymph node metastasis

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with persistent hoarseness for the past 2 months. Laryngoscopy reveals a small lesion on the anterior third of the right vocal cord with normal cord mobility. Further investigations lead to the diagnosis of Glottic laryngeal carcinoma. Which of the following statements about the condition is incorrect ?

choices.text: It is the most common site of origin for glottic carcinoma
Hoarseness is typically an early symptom
Lymph node metastases are common in early stages
Histopathologically well differentiated and less malignant

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Lymph node metastases are common in early stages

 

Explanation:

  • Nodal metastases are typically never seen in glottic laryngeal carcinoma.
  • There are few lymphatics in vocal cords, and nodal metastases are practically never seen, unless the disease spreads beyond the region of the membranous cord.

Glottic laryngeal carcinoma

Incidence
  • Most common site of laryngeal cancer origin (Option A)

Site
  • Free edge and upper surface of vocal cord, mainly in anterior and middle third

Vocal cord involvement
  • Involvement of vocal cord occurs early so the patient presents early with hoarseness of voice (Option B)
  • Vocal cord fixation indicates spread to thyroarytenoid muscle and is a bad prognostic sign

Lymphatic spread
  • Rare due to few lymphatics in vocal cords

Local Spread
  • Can spread locally to anterior commissure, opposite cord, arytenoid region, ventricle, false cord, and subglottic region

Symptoms
  • Hoarseness is an early sign; stridor and laryngeal obstruction in advanced cases

Histopathology
  • Well differentiated and less malignant (Option D)

 

References:

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents with dysphagia, throat pain, and a palpable neck mass. Laryngoscopy reveals a lesion on the epiglottis. Further investigations lead to the diagnosis of Laryngeal carcinoma.Which of the following is not a typical characteristic of this condition?

choices.text: Bilateral lymph node metastases are common but occurs late
Hoarseness is usually a late symptom
The most common histological type is squamous cell carcinoma
It may spread to the pre-epiglottic space

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Bilateral lymph node metastases are common but occurs late

 

Explanation:

The involvement of epiglottis in laryngeal carcinoma is indicative of supraglottic laryngeal carcinoma, in which nodal metastases occur early and are commonly bilateral.

Supraglottic Laryngeal Carcinoma:

Incidence

Less frequent than glottic cancer; about 30-35% of all laryngeal cancers

Site

Majority on epiglottis, false cords, followed by aryepiglottic folds

Vocal cord involvement

Usually late; vocal cords often spared in early stages

Lymphatic spread
  • Early and often bilateral
  • Upper and middle jugular nodes commonly involved
  • Cancer of infrahyoid epiglottis & anterior ventricular band may extend into pre-epiglottic space (Option D)

Symptoms
  • Early: Often silent, dysphagia, throat pain
  • Late: Hoarseness, weight loss, respiratory obstruction, halitosis (Option B)

Histopathology
  • 90-95% squamous cell carcinoma (Option C)
  • Others include verrucous carcinoma, spindle cell carcinoma
  • Highly anaplastic

Prognosis

Generally worse than glottic cancer due to:

  • Late diagnosis
  • High rate & early lymph node metastasis
  • Anaplastic nature

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the laryngeal nerve supply is incorrect?

choices.text: The right recurrent laryngeal nerve arises from the vagus at the level of the subclavian artery, while the left recurrent laryngeal nerve arises at the level of the arch of the aorta.
The internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve provides sensory innervation to the larynx below the vocal cords.
The external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve innervates the cricothyroid muscle.
The left recurrent laryngeal nerve has a longer course than the right, making it more prone to paralysis.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) The internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve provides sensory innervation to the larynx below the vocal cords.

 

Explanation:

The larynx receives both motor and sensory nerve supply from branches of the vagus nerve.

 

Motor innervation:

  • Recurrent laryngeal nerve - All muscles that move the vocal cords, including abductors, adductors, and tensors. Except the cricothyroid muscle.
  • External branch of the superior laryngeal nerve - cricothyroid muscle. (Option C)

 

Sensory innervation:

  • The internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve - above the vocal cords. (Option B)
  • Recurrent laryngeal nerve - below the vocal cords.

 

Recurrent laryngeal nerve anatomy:

  • The right recurrent laryngeal nerve branches from the vagus at the level of the subclavian artery, looping around it before ascending between the trachea and esophagus. (Option A)
  • The left recurrent laryngeal nerve arises at the arch of the aorta, loops around it, and ascends along the tracheoesophageal groove, giving it a longer course compared to the right nerve, making it more prone to injury. (Option A and D)

 

Superior laryngeal nerve:

  • Origin - from the inferior ganglion of the vagus nerve; courses behind the internal carotid artery; divides into external and internal branches at the level of the greater cornua of the hyoid bone.
  • The external branch innervates the cricothyroid muscle.
  • The internal branch provides sensory innervation to the larynx and hypopharynx after piercing through the thyrohyoid membrane.

questions.text: During a thyroidectomy, the surgeon encounters difficulty identifying the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (EBSLN). To improve nerve visualization, the surgeon decides to explore a specific avascular space between the upper pole of the thyroid gland and the cricothyroid muscle. Which of the following spaces is the surgeon aiming to open to aid in the preservation of the EBSLN?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Reeve’s space

 

Explanation:

  • Reeve’s Space is the avascular space between the upper pole of the thyroid gland and the cricothyroid muscle.
  • Identifying and opening this space is crucial for locating and preserving the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (EBSLN).

 

Cricothyroid space of Reeves:

  • An avascular space crucial for the identification and preservation of the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (EBSLN).
  • Location: Found between the upper pole of the thyroid gland and the cricothyroid muscle.
  • Identification: Achieved by performing medial dissection at the superior pole of the thyroid gland.
  • Opening the Space: The ipsilateral thyroid lobe is pulled downward and outward.
  • Relation to Joll’s Triangle: Opening Reeve’s Space helps in accessing and exposing Joll’s Triangle (sternothyroid-laryngeal triangle), which is used to identify the EBSLN.

Reinke’s Space (Option A) is located under the epithelium of the vocal cords and is involved in conditions like Reinke’s edema.

  • It does not relate to the identification of the EBSLN.

Space of Boyer (Option C) or the Preepiglottic Space is bounded by the thyroid cartilage, thyrohyoid membrane, hyoepiglottic ligament, and the quadrangular membrane.

  • It is not related to the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (EBSLN).

Paraglottic Space (Option D) is located between the thyroid cartilage and the ventricle, and it is continuous with the preepiglottic space.

  • This space is not specifically used for identifying the EBSLN but is more relevant in cases of laryngeal tumors.

questions.text: Joll’s Triangle is used to identify which of the following nerves?

choices.text: External Branch of the Superior Laryngeal Nerve
Internal Branch of the Superior Laryngeal Nerve

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) External Branch of the Superior Laryngeal Nerve

 

Explanation:

Joll’s Triangle is designed to help identify and preserve the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (EBSLN) during surgery.

 

Joll’s Triangle (Sternothyroid-laryngeal triangle)

An anatomical landmark used for identifying and preserving the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (EBSLN).

  • Superior border by the upper attachment of the strap muscles.
  • Medial border by the midline of the neck.
  • Lateral border by the upper pole of the thyroid gland and the superior thyroid vessels.
  • Floor of the Triangle: The EBSLN is located in the floor of the triangle, which is delineated by the cricothyroid muscle.


 

Joll’s Triangle is not used for locating the Recurrent laryngeal nerve (Option A) or Internal Branch of the Superior Laryngeal Nerve (Option C) or Vagus Nerve (Option D).

questions.text: Which of the following triangles is not used to identify the recurrent laryngeal nerve?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Joll’s triangle

Explanation:

Joll’s Triangle is specifically used for identifying and preserving the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (EBSLN), not the recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN).

 

RLN identification triangles

Description

Beahrs Triangle (Riddle’s Triangle) (Option C)

 

  • Boundaries:
    • Common carotid artery (base)
    • Inferior thyroid artery (superior)
    • Recurrent laryngeal nerve (third side)
  • Location: Posterior to thyroid gland in the tracheoesophageal groove.
  • Importance: Used to safeguard the recurrent laryngeal nerve during thyroid surgery

Simon’s Triangle (Option A)


 
  • Boundaries:
    • Common carotid artery (lateral)
    • Esophagus (medial)
    • Inferior thyroid artery (superior)
  • Importance: RLN crosses the triangle and is identified intraoperatively.

Lore’s Triangle (Option D)


 
  • Boundaries:
    • Trachea/esophagus (medial)
    • Common carotid artery (lateral)
    • Surface of the inferior pole of thyroid (superior)
  • Importance: Used for identification of the recurrent laryngeal nerve.

Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve (RLN) Triangle
  • Boundaries:
    • Apex: Thoracic inlet (inferior)
    • Medial: Trachea
    • Lateral: Medial edge of retracted strap muscles
    • Superior: Lower edge of inferior thyroid pole
  • Importance: RLN exits as a single trunk at the thoracic inlet.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male underwent total thyroidectomy for a large multinodular goiter. Postoperatively, he presents with complete loss of voice, frequent aspiration of liquids, and an inability to cough effectively. On laryngoscopy, both vocal cords are found in a cadaveric position, and there is no sensation in the larynx. He is also experiencing difficulty breathing and frequent episodes of bronchopneumonia. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Unilateral recurrent and superior laryngeal nerve paralysis
Bilateral recurrent and superior laryngeal nerve paralysis

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Bilateral recurrent and superior laryngeal nerve paralysis

 

Explanation:

  • Bilateral recurrent and superior laryngeal nerve paralysis explains the complete loss of voice (aphonia), total paralysis of both vocal cords in the cadaveric position, laryngeal anesthesia, aspiration, and recurrent bronchopneumonia described in the scenario.
  • It is a known complication of thyroid surgery.

 

Feature

Unilateral Combined Paralysis

Bilateral Combined Paralysis

Affected Nerves
  • One side (Recurrent and Superior Laryngeal Nerves)
  • Thyroid surgery is the most common cause.
  • Both sides (Recurrent and Superior Laryngeal Nerves)

Vocal Cord Position
  • Paralyzed cord in cadaveric position (3.5 mm from midline)
  • Healthy cord unable to fully approximate paralyzed cord
  • Both cords in the cadaveric (Intermediate) position (neutral, apart from midline)
  • Complete lack of movement in both cords

Clinical Features
  • All the muscles of the larynx on one side are paralyzed except the interarytenoid.
  • Hoarseness: Due to glottic incompetence
  • Aspiration: Liquids pass through the glottis
  • Ineffective cough: Due to air waste from incomplete vocal fold closure
  • Mild aspiration risk
  • Breathing: Usually unaffected as airway remains adequate
  • Speech: Weak or breathy, but functional
  • All the laryngeal muscles are paralyzed.
  • Total anesthesia of the larynx.
  • Aphonia: Complete loss of voice as cords do not meet
  • Severe aspiration: Total glottic incompetence, laryngeal anesthesia
  • Inability to cough: Cords cannot meet to generate pressure for coughing
  • Bronchopneumonia: Due to frequent aspiration of secretions into the lungs
  • Respiratory distress: Due to compromised airway and retention of secretions
  • Speech: Completely absent

Treatment
  • Voice therapy - for compensation by the healthy cord
  • Injection laryngoplasty (temporary or permanent fillers)
  • Thyroplasty Type I with or without arytenoid adduction
  • Tracheostomy to clear pulmonary secretions
  • Gastrostomy to prevent aspiration and maintain nutrition
  • Epiglottopexy to prevent aspiration
  • Vocal cord plication to prevent aspiration
  • Total laryngectomy or diversion procedures in severe cases


 

Bilateral superior laryngeal nerve paralysis (Option A) primarily affects the cricothyroid muscles, leading to a weak and husky voice, but not complete aphonia or significant airway obstruction.

  • There is typically upper laryngeal anesthesia causing aspiration and coughing fits, but both vocal cords remain mobile. This does not fully explain the severe symptoms described in the scenario (total voice loss and significant aspiration).

 

Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve paralysis (Option B) leads to airway obstruction with both cords in a median or paramedian position, causing dyspnea and stridor, but the voice would typically remain intact.

  • The airway compromise described here is much more severe, and aphonia and laryngeal anesthesia suggest additional nerve involvement.

 

Unilateral recurrent and superior laryngeal nerve paralysis (Option C) would cause hoarseness and aspiration on one side, but not complete aphonia or severe respiratory issues.

  • The healthy side usually compensates, which is inconsistent with the symptoms described in the scenario (bilateral involvement, total loss of voice).

questions.text: A 45-year-old professional singer presents with complaints of vocal fatigue and difficulty producing high-pitched sounds for the last 3 months. She denies any difficulty in swallowing or breathing. On laryngoscopic examination, no significant abnormalities are seen, and one vocal cord appears to be in normal resting position while other vocal cord is in abducted position . What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Unilateral SLN palsy

 

Explanation:

  • In this scenario, the patient is a professional singer who reports difficulty with high-pitched sounds, which is a hallmark of unilateral SLN palsy.
  • The external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve innervates the cricothyroid muscle, which tenses the vocal cords, crucial for producing high-pitched sounds.
  • In unilateral SLN palsy, the patient does not experience breathing or swallowing difficulties, and laryngoscopic examination may appear normal.

 

Unilateral SLN Palsy

  • Motor Loss: Cricothyroid muscle - decreased ability to tense the vocal cord.
  • Sensory Loss: Above the vocal cord on the affected side.
  • Vocal Cord Position: The affected vocal cord appears shortened and wavy; may exhibit flapping due to loss of tension.
  • Other Features:
    • Askew position of the glottis with the anterior commissure rotated towards the healthy side.
    • Voice changes such as weakness and inability to raise pitch, affecting singing ability.
  • Treatment: Primarily voice therapy to improve vocal function and manage symptoms.

 

Bilateral SLN Palsy

  • Motor Loss: Both cricothyroid muscles - bilateral loss of vocal cord tension.
  • Sensory Loss: Above the vocal cords bilaterally.
  • Vocal Cord Position: Both vocal cords may be shortened and lack tension, potentially leading to difficulties with voice production.
  • Other Features:
    • Inhalation of food and secretions resulting in coughing and choking.
    • The voice is weak and husky.
  • Treatment:
    • Tracheostomy with a cuffed tube and esophageal feeding tube, if aspiration is severe.
    • Epiglottopexy (reversible) - close laryngeal inlet - to protect the lungs from aspiration.
    • Voice pitch improvement through surgical approximation of the thyroid and cricoid cartilages.

 

Bilateral SLN palsy (Option A):

  • The patient would have more pronounced symptoms, including a monotonous voice, significant difficulty with high-pitched sounds, and aspiration due to poor sensation in the upper larynx.

 

Unilateral RLN palsy (Option C)

  • Causes hoarseness and, on laryngoscopy, shows one vocal cord in a paramedian position.
  • In contrast, this patient's difficulty is specifically related to high-pitched sounds, pointing to SLN involvement rather than RLN.

 

Bilateral RLN palsy (Option D):

  • It is a severe condition that typically results in stridor or significant respiratory difficulty due to both vocal cords being fixed in the paramedian position.
  • The absence of breathing or swallowing problems in this patient rules out bilateral RLN palsy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with hoarseness , shortness of breath and stridor following thyroid surgery. Laryngoscopy reveals bilateral vocal cord paralysis with both cords fixed in paramedian position. Which of the following is the most appropriate immediate management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Tracheostomy

Explanation:

 

  • This patient presents with symptoms and laryngoscopic findings consistent with bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) palsy, likely due to iatrogenic injury during thyroid surgery.
  • In bilateral RLN palsy, both vocal cords are typically fixed in a paramedian or intermediate position, leading to a narrow airway.
  • This can cause severe dyspnea and stridor, potentially life-threatening complications.
  • The immediate priority in managing such cases is to secure the airway, which is best achieved through a tracheostomy.

Recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) palsy can occur either unilaterally or bilaterally, leading to varying clinical manifestations and airway complications.

Vocal cord lateralization (Option B): While this is a treatment option for bilateral RLN palsy, it is not the immediate management of choice.

  • This procedure is typically considered after the airway is secured and the patient is stabilized.

 

Arytenoidectomy (Option C): This is another surgical option for treating bilateral RLN palsy, but like vocal cord lateralization, it's not the immediate management of choice.

  • This is usually considered at a later stage if other options fail.

 

Observation and voice therapy (Option D): This approach is inadequate for bilateral RLN palsy with significant airway compromise.

  • While voice therapy can be beneficial in the long-term management of RLN palsy, it does not address the immediate airway emergency presented in this scenario.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is primarily responsible for adducting the vocal folds and closing the rima glottidis during phonation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Lateral cricoarytenoid muscle

 

Explanation:

  • The lateral cricoarytenoid muscle is primarily responsible for adducting the vocal folds and closing the rima glottidis during phonation.
  • It rotates the arytenoid cartilage internally, bringing the vocal processes and vocal folds together.

 

Phonation:

  • The process of sound production in the larynx as air passes through the vocal cords.
  • During this process, the vocal cords or vocal folds adduct and vibrate as air from the lungs passes through the narrow space between them, the glottis.

 

Various intrinsic laryngeal muscles regulate the tension, length, and position of the vocal cords:

  • Posterior cricoarytenoid muscle: vocal cord abduction, facilitating the opening of the rima glottidis. (Option A)

  • Lateral cricoarytenoid, interarytenoid, and thyroarytenoid muscles: adduct the vocal cords, resulting in the closure of the rima glottidis. (Option B)
  • Cricothyroid and vocalis muscles: Increase tension in the vocal cords.

  • Thyroepiglottic muscle: Opens the laryngeal inlet. (Option C)
  • Aryepiglottic and oblique arytenoid muscles: Close the laryngeal inlet.

 

Phonation depends on neural control through the following nerves:

  • The recurrent laryngeal nerve - most of the intrinsic laryngeal muscles
  • The superior laryngeal nerve - the cricothyroid muscle- is essential for modulating pitch.

 

Thyrohyoid muscle (Option D): This is an extrinsic laryngeal muscle. It elevates the larynx and depresses the hyoid bone.

  • While it plays a role in laryngeal positioning, it does not directly adduct the vocal folds.
